channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Hunt to Arm Ukraine Leads to Difficult Choices for Some Nations
item.description: The U.S. and NATO are scouring the world for new sources of old weapons to send to Ukraine. But it risks as much peril for some nations as it does promise for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with a Soviet-style assault rifle in Irpin in March. Ukrainian officials say their stockpiles of Soviet-style weapons, which many soldiers were trained to use, are running dangerously low.

item.title: Biden to Re-evaluate Relationship With Saudi Arabia After Oil Production Cut
item.description: Angered by the kingdom’s decision to team up with Russia to slash petroleum output, the president signaled openness to retaliatory measures, including a halt to arms sales and a new antitrust measure.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s willingness to consider retaliatory measures represents a significant shift for a president who had sought to improve relations with Saudi Arabia in recent months.

item.title: What Russia’s Missile Strikes May Indicate About Its Weapons Stockpile
item.description: Russia’s assault on Ukraine on Monday raised questions about the capacity of Moscow’s forces to carry out President Vladimir V. Putin’s military calculations.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian rocket serves as a reminder of the relentless bombardment of Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Angela Lansbury, TV’s Favorite Sleuth on ‘Murder She Wrote,’ Dies at 96
item.description: She was a Hollywood and Broadway sensation, but she captured the biggest audience of her career as the TV sleuth Jessica Fletcher.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Lewis
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times

item.title: Christina Bobb, a Trump Lawyer, Is Under Justice Dept. Scrutiny
item.description: Christina Bobb is a former Marine and a fervent believer that the 2020 election was stolen from Donald J. Trump. She went to work for him and quickly found herself enmeshed in an obstruction investigation.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Megan Mendoza/The Republic, via USA Today Network
item.media:description: Christina Bobb, a former One America News Network anchor, was a late addition to former President Donald J. Trump’s legal team. She is now at the heart of the Justice Department’s criminal investigation into his handling of White House documents.

item.title: Biden Administration Considering Humanitarian Parole Program for Venezuelans
item.description: The U.S. hopes such a program will discourage more Venezuelans from crossing the border illegally.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: More than 150,000 Venezuelans have been apprehended at the southwestern U.S. border between October 2021 through the end of August.

item.title: For Venezuelan Migrants in South Florida, ‘Vision of a Certain Life’ Meets Reality
item.description: Doral, Fla., nicknamed “Doralzuela,” has become a destination for the many people fleeing a troubled country. There, they find support, and, ideally, a new home.
item.dc:creator: Peter Kujawinski and Erin Kirkland for The New York Times
item.media:credit: Erin Kirkland for The New York Times

item.title: Dozens of Candidates of Color Give House Republicans a Path to Diversity
item.description: The party has fielded 67 Black, Latino, Asian or Native American candidates for the House, by its count, and the number in Congress is almost certain to grow.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Christian K Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wesley Hunt, left, is likely to win his House race in Texas and add to the ranks of Black Republicans in the chamber, where there are currently only two.

item.title: In Fight for Congress, a Surprising Battleground Emerges: New York
item.description: After a haywire redistricting process, New York has more congressional battlegrounds than nearly any other state. Even the Democratic campaign chairman is locked in a dead heat.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos

item.title: NASA DART Spacecraft Successfully Smashed Asteroid Into New Orbit
item.description: The DART mission proved more successful than expected in adjusting the trajectory of Dimorphos, suggesting that a deadly space rock could be deflected in the future.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Scoles
item.media:credit: NASA/ESA/STScI/Hubble
item.media:description: An image captured by NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope on Oct. 8 showed a tail of debris blasted from the surface of Dimorphos 285 hours after the collision with the DART spacecraft.

item.title: Elon Musk Has the World’s Strangest Social Calendar
item.description: When the world’s richest man isn’t tweeting, he’s flying to Burning Man, trying to impress comedians and hopping on yachts.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Bernstein
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri/Getty Images
item.media:description: Elon Musk at this year’s Met Gala in New York.

item.title: IMF Warns Rate Increases Could Spur A Global Recession
item.description: The International Monetary Fund lowered its growth outlook for 2023 and suggested that interest rate increases could spur a harsh global recession.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Shawn Thew/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: “The risks are accumulating,” said Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas, the International Monetary Fund’s chief economist, right.

item.title: Bank of England Expands Market Intervention to Avoid a ‘Fire Sale’
item.description: In the final week of its emergency bond-buying program, the central bank is expanding its efforts to restore bond market function.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: For the past two and a half weeks, Britain’s financial markets have faced turmoil after investors rebuffed the tax-cutting and spending policies of Prime Minister Liz Truss and her new government.

item.title: Adnan Syed’s Charges Are Dropped by Baltimore Prosecutors
item.description: Mr. Syed, whose case was featured in the hit podcast “Serial,” had been convicted in the death of a high school classmate and spent 23 years in prison before being released last month.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adnan Syed, the subject of the podcast “Serial,” leaving Baltimore City Circuit Court last month after a judge overturned his murder conviction in September.

item.title: Rick Martínez’s Essential Mexican Recipes
item.description: The “Mi Cocina” author and a second-generation Mexican American shares the regional specialties he loves most.
item.dc:creator: Rick A. Martínez
item.media:credit: Ren Fuller for The New York Times. Food Stylist:Laura Kinsey Dolph. Prop Stylist: Tamasin Reid.

item.title: What Teenagers’ Mental Health Can Tell Us About America
item.description: Adolescents live at the fault lines of a culture, exposing our weak spots.
item.dc:creator: Jamieson Webster
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chantal Jahchan. Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Why Do People Think Going to Therapy Makes You a Good Person?
item.description: The recent focus on therapy as a cure-all overlooks that there are other ways to heal.
item.dc:creator: Mychal Denzel Smith
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie; photograph by Getty Images/iStockphoto

item.title: How Facebook Triggers My Bipolar Disorder
item.description: Social media didn’t cause my mental illness, but it exacerbated it. Now I have found a way to quiet the noise.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Eisler Vance
item.media:credit: Tommy Kha for The New York Times

item.title: This Is What Happens When Election Deniers Let Their Freak Flag Fly
item.description: The 2020-was-rigged crowd has ambitious plans.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times

item.title: A Nobel Prize for the Economics of Panic
item.description: The prize recognized important work explaining when and why financial markets implode.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by vanbeets and Bettmann via Getty Images

item.title: Joe Biden Knows How to Use Donald Trump
item.description: A lot of politicians would have vied with Trump to make the election about them.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Who Should Your ‘Work Self’ Be?
item.description: Readers discuss whether people should be their “whole selves” at work. Also: The Iranian women’s revolt; nuclear radiation; jobs for migrants.

item.title: Russia’s Revenge
item.description: After weeks of setbacks on the battlefield, Russia struck civilian targets in Ukraine. But Vladimir Putin’s missiles may not accomplish much.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: The Rise of the Single-Family Home
item.description: They may have become a cherished feature of American life, but in California, such dwellings are a driver of soaring house prices.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Stella Tan, Luke Vander Ploeg, Kaitlin Roberts, Will Reid, Anita Badejo, Rowan Niemisto, Chelsea Daniel and Marion Lozano
item.media:credit: Sandy Huffaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Baxter Street in San Diego. In the 1950s, the area was marketed as a quiet suburb of single-family homes just a few minutes’ drive from schools and a shopping center, along with downtown and the beach.

item.title: How to Learn My Love Language
item.description: A Deaf man has been let down by every lover he’s ever had. This time might be different.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Tell Us: What Questions About Climate Change Can We Answer?
item.description: There is no question too basic, or too big. Your suggestions will be used to help guide the Times’s climate coverage.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Israel and Lebanon Reach Landmark Maritime Agreement
item.description: If ratified by both governments, the deal is expected to avert the immediate threat of conflict between Israel and Hezbollah, and could eventually help salve energy shortages.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Jalaa Marey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An Israeli navy vessel patrolled the Mediterranean waters off Rosh Hanikra on the border between Israel and Lebanon on Friday.

item.title: As Hospitals Close Children’s Units, Where Does That Leave Lachlan?
item.description: Adult beds are more lucrative than children’s beds. So as institutions look to boost profit margins, pediatrics is often among the first services to be cut.
item.dc:creator: Emily Baumgaertner
item.media:credit: Melissa Lukenbaugh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lachlan’s morning routine involves time with the inhaler after breakfast while preparing for school.

item.title: With Fall Migration, Bird Flu Flies Back Into Town
item.description: Zoos, bird rescue groups and other animal facilities are grappling with a “radically different” outbreak of avian influenza.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
item.media:credit: Wisconsin Humane Society, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of the Wisconsin Humane Society treated a bald eagle that later tested positive for avian influenza this spring.

item.title: Lawsuit Says Charity Leader Hired His Former Personal Trainer for Key Role
item.description: Spending by a charity intended to honor a radio pioneer is being challenged by his granddaughter, who says he was tricked into leaving his fortune to it. The charity denies the charge and says the producer did not trust his family to protect his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Himan Brown, right, directing Betty Winkler and Frank Lovejoy at a radio studio in New York in 1943.

item.title: Flu Shot: What to Know About Side Effects, Protection and Timing
item.description: And everything else you’ve been wondering about this annual vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: New Study Strengthens the Link Between Exercise and Memory
item.description: Experts have long known that fitness is good for the brain. A recent paper connects different types of workouts with assorted improvements in memory.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Does CBD Help With Insomnia?
item.description: The research is sparse, experts say, but there are some hints about how it could soothe you to sleep.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Gravel Biking is Getting Popular. Here’s How to Start.
item.description: A faster bicycle design with thicker tires is allowing cyclists to explore America’s 2.2 million miles of Here’s what you need to know about this new sport.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Singleton
item.media:credit: Alex Goodlett for The New York Times

item.title: How Do You Manage Omicron BA.5 Symptoms, Including a Sore Throat?
item.description: The longtime symptom of Covid is becoming more common, and sometimes more severe, with the dominant BA.5 subvariant.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: For Latin American Women, Horror and Fantasy Capture Everyday Struggle
item.description: Aiming to unsettle readers and offer social critique, writers like Samanta Schweblin and Mónica Ojeda are in a new vanguard.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin P. Russell
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Argentine writer Samanta Schweblin’s “Seven Empty Houses” is a National Book Award finalist for works in translation.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
